009
010package imagingbook.common.color.adapt;
011
012import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.inverse;
013import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.multiply;
014
015import imagingbook.common.color.cie.Illuminant;
016
017/**
018 * <p>
019 * This class represents a linear chromatic adaptation transform,
020 * mapping XYZ color coordinates from a source white (reference) point
021 * to a target white point. 
022 * Both white points are passed to the constructor.
023 * The actual color mapping is done by method {@link #applyTo(float[])}.
024 * The underlying linear transformation is specified by a 3x3 matrix,
025 * which may be retrieved by {@link #getAdaptationMatrix()}).
026 * See Sec. 14.6 of [1] for additional details and examples.
027 * </p>
028 * <p>
029 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; 
030 * An Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
031 * </p>
032 * 
033 * @author WB
034 * @version 2022/11/14
035 * @see XYZscalingAdaptation
036 */
037public class BradfordAdaptation implements ChromaticAdaptation {
038        
039        // CAT forward transform matrix from XYZ to "virtual" RGB scaling coordinates
040        private static final double[][] MCAT = {
041            { 0.8951,  0.2664, -0.1614},
042            {-0.7502,  1.7135,  0.0367},
043            { 0.0389, -0.0685,  1.0296}};
044           
045        // CAT inverse transform matrix from "virtual" RGB scaling coordinates back to XYZ
046        private static final double[][] MCATi = inverse(MCAT);    // we always invert for precision reasons
047//              {{ 0.9869929054667120, -0.1470542564209900, 0.1599626516637310}, 
048//               { 0.4323052697233940,  0.5183602715367770, 0.0492912282128560}, 
049//               {-0.0085286645751770,  0.0400428216540850, 0.9684866957875500}}
050        
051        // the complete color adaptation transformation matrix for transforming source XYZ to target XYZ,
052        // XYZ2 = Madapt * XYZ1, with
053        // Madapt = MCAT^-1 * DiagRGB * MCAT
054        private final double[][] Madapt;
055        private final double[][] Mdiag;
056        
057        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
058        
059        /**
060         * Returns a {@link BradfordAdaptation} instance for the specified
061         * white point coordinates.
062         * 
063         * @param W1 source white point (to map from)
064         * @param W2 target white point (to map to)
065         * @return a {@link BradfordAdaptation} instance 
066         */
067        public static BradfordAdaptation getInstance(double[] W1, double[] W2) {
068                return new BradfordAdaptation(W1, W2);
069        }
070        
071        /**
072         * Returns a {@link BradfordAdaptation} instance for the specified
073         * illuminants (white points).
074         * 
075         * @param illum1 source illuminant (white point to map from)
076         * @param illum2 target illuminant (white point to map to)
077         * @return a {@link BradfordAdaptation} instance
078         */
079        public static BradfordAdaptation getInstance(Illuminant illum1, Illuminant illum2) {
080                return getInstance(illum1.getXYZ(), illum2.getXYZ());
081        }
082        
083        /** Constructor (non-public) accepting two white points (XYZ-coordinates). */
084        private BradfordAdaptation(double[] W1, double[] W2) {
085                double[] rgb1 = multiply(MCAT, W1);
086                double[] rgb2 = multiply(MCAT, W2);
087                this.Mdiag = getRgbWhiteRatioMatrix(rgb1, rgb2);
088                this.Madapt = multiply(MCATi, multiply(Mdiag, MCAT));
089        }
090        
091        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
092        
093        public static double[][] getMCAT() {
094                return MCAT;
095        }
096        
097        public static double[][] getMCATi() {
098                return MCATi;
099        }
100        
101        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
102        
103        @Override
104        public float[] applyTo(float[] XYZA) {
105                // XYZB = Madapt . XYZA
106                float[] XYZB = new float[3];
107                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
108                        XYZB[i] = (float) (Madapt[i][0] * XYZA[0] + Madapt[i][1] * XYZA[1] + Madapt[i][2] * XYZA[2]);
109                }
110                return XYZB;
111        }
112        
113        @Override
114        public double[] applyTo(double[] XYZA) {
115                // XYZB = Madapt . XYZA
116                double[] XYZB = new double[3];
117                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
118                        XYZB[i] = Madapt[i][0] * XYZA[0] + Madapt[i][1] * XYZA[1] + Madapt[i][2] * XYZA[2];
119                }
120                return XYZB;
121        }
122        
123        /**
124         * Returns the composite color adaptation transformation matrix.
125         * @return the color adaptation transformation matrix
126         */
127        public double[][] getAdaptationMatrix() {
128                return this.Madapt;
129        }
130        
131
132        // Creates a diagonal matrix with the ratios of the rgb components
133        // obtained by transforming the two white points
134        private static double[][] getRgbWhiteRatioMatrix(double[] rgbA, double[] rgbB) {
135                if (rgbA.length != rgbB.length) {
136                        throw new IllegalArgumentException();
137                }
138                final int n = rgbA.length;
139                double[][] M = new double[n][n];
140                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
141                        M[i][i] = rgbB[i] / rgbA[i];
142                }
143                return M;
144        }
145                
146}
